en.value: I got a job!
Talking about our career and work history - Past simple recap
I worked as a…
Here's a tip!
We're now going to look at how we can talk about our past jobs. We'll learn things like:
I was at my last job for 5 years.
Why did you quit your job?
I left my previous company to go travelling.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
to be at
I was at my last job for 5 years.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
I [k]w[/k][k]a[/k][k]s[/k] [k]a[/k][k]t[/k] my last job for 5 years.
to work as
He worked as a waiter in a hotel.
He [k]worked[/k] as a waiter in a hotel.
working
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
to quit
Why did you quit your job?
True or false?
This sentence contains the past simple form of the verb "to quit".
Why did you quit your job?
to earn
She didn't earn enough at her previous job.
Listen to the dialogue. Select the most accurate statement.
Filippo quit his last job because he wasn't earning enough.
Filippo worked as a designer in Madrid until he left last year.
Filippo was at his last job for fourteen years before he quit.
to get a job as
I got a job as a teaching assistant in the local school.
Listen and select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
I [k]got[/k] a job at a company in Sweden. I'm moving there next month.
quit
to leave
I left my previous company to go travelling.
Match the pairs of words / phrases.
Why did you
He worked as
She earned
leave your last job?
an accountant for two years.
more at her last job.
Read and listen to the word and the key phrase.
company
What's the name of the company you were working for last year?
I left my previous [k]c[/k][k]o[/k][k]m[/k][k]p[/k][k]a[/k][k]n[/k][k]y[/k] to move here.
To recap, here are the words and expressions we've just seen:
to be at
to work as
to quit
to earn
to get a job as
to leave
company
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Why did you [k]leave[/k] your last company?
Well, I [k]was at[/k] my last job for 11 years. I needed a change, so I quit to go travelling.
That's so interesting.
How about you?
I [k]quit[/k] my job because I didn't [k]earn[/k] enough there. My current salary is much better, but I [k]worked[/k] at my last job for a long time, almost 10 years, and I miss the people there.
I get what you mean.
Regina
Axel
Listen to the audio. Select the most accurate statement.
Regina left her job because she didn't earn enough.
Regina left her job because she went travelling.
Regina left her job because she needed a change.
Listen to the dialogue. Why did Axel quit his job?
He fancied a change and decided to go travelling.
He didn't like the company that he worked for.
He wanted to find a job in a different country.
Fill in the gap using the audio.
[k]Why did you quit[/k] your job?
Select the words in the correct order.
[k]I[/k] [k]got[/k] [k]a job[/k] [k]as[/k] [k]an accountant.[/k]
Regina worked at her last job for almost 10 years.
Regina earned a lot more at her previous company.
Regina quit her last job to move to Montenegro.
What's the name of the [k]company[/k] you were working for last year?
[k]She[/k] [k]was[/k] [k]at[/k] [k]her last job[/k] [k]for 7 years[/k].
I needed a change, so [k]I quit[/k] to go travelling.
Describe your last job. How long were you there? Why did you leave?
I worked as a waiter for two years. I left to go to university.
Grammar: Past simple recap
Let's recap!
We've recently learned the "past simple" tense. It's used quite frequently, so let's recap the main points and practise it some more to make sure you're confident recognising and using it.
I studied French at school.
She left early.
He didn't cook dinner.
Did you move house?
Listen carefully.
Mara and Ben are catching up.
What [k]did you have[/k] for dinner last night?
do you have
Listen to the audio. Which statement is true?
Mara went out for dinner.
Mara's boyfriend John cooked.
Mara cooked for John.
I had a really nice spaghetti arrabbiata.
This sentence talks about the past.
Complete the sentence with the correct past simple form of the verb.
John [k]wanted[/k] to cook.
wants
They ate out because their fridge was empty.
Mara had dinner at a restaurant with friends.
John made pasta for Mara.
They didn't get a table in the city centre.
They didn't like the restaurant in the centre.
They preferred to be near the park.
We went to "Amore Mio" near the park.
They're going to go to a restaurant near the park.
This sentence is about the past. They already went to the restaurant.
Ben met his girlfriend at the restaurant near the park.
Ben is meeting his girlfriend at the restaurant too.
Ben went for dinner with Mara and John.
I love that place, we should go together.
This sentence is in the present simple tense.
Before we practise some more, let's quickly summarise the points we've learned so far.
We form the past simple of regular verbs by adding "-ed", "-d" or "-ied".
We have to memorise the past simple form of irregular verbs as we go.
We form negative sentences in the past simple with the structure: person / thing + "did" + "not" + verb (base form).
For questions in the past simple, we follow the structure: "did" + person + verb (base form)
We [k]were[/k] really hungry.
was
[k]Did[/k] [k]you[/k] [k]cook[/k] [k]dinner[/k] [k]at home?[/k]
Select the correct words to fill the gaps.
Present simple
Past simple
go
went
meet
met
leave
left
got
meat
We [k]walked[/k] to the Italian restaurant near the park.
walk
She [k]read[/k] the menu twice before she ordered.
[k]We[/k] [k]did[/k] [k]not[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]dessert[/k].
Mara [k]ordered[/k] pasta.
orders
Complete the sentence in the simple past.
[k]Did[/k] you [k]have[/k] pasta too?
Do
ate
Complete the sentence with the correct past simple form of the verb "have".
No, I [k]had[/k] pizza.
Re-write the question in the past simple.
[k]Did you like your food[/k]?
Do you like your food?
Match up the verbs with their past simple form.
to read
to get
to meet
read
got
met
We [k]were[/k] very happy with our meal.
Re-write the sentence to make it negative.
[k]We did not have dessert|We didn't have dessert[/k].
We had dessert.
